content.webTitle: Spiral recap: season seven, episodes three and four – not tonight, Joséphine

fields.headline: Spiral recap: season seven, episodes three and four – not tonight, Joséphine
fields.bodyText: Spoiler alert: this recap is for people watching Spiral on the BBC. Do not read on unless you have watched season seven, episodes three and four. Money talks If you’re counting, €329,510 fell out of that loft last week, which is a decent haul for some dopey kids putting in a few minutes’ work. The current understanding is that Herville’s informant Wang was holding drugs and money for the Curial estate gangsters, headed by Nassir Benslimane. In the garment district, we’ve got pillar of the Wen community Mr Chen running Agathe Passion and Wang’s partner in the Chinese restaurant Wei Xu running Street Fashion. The rag trade washes the dirty money, and so the gears of the black economy keep turning. The vital intel comes from Kader – but not before he plays Ali like a harpsichord, getting a witness’s name and address from him without lifting a finger. As a result, the witness catches a beatdown and her flat gets trashed. Ali’s misstep is so knuckleheaded it calls to mind prime Gilou. This new kid is fitting in just fine. The squad are nothing if not persistent, though, and they get their first big break when they discover Rayan’s brother Fouad transporting cash for the Chinese. With Rayan now in custody, Fouad’s next visit suddenly becomes a lot more interesting. Gilou Some nice buddy comedy develops between Ali and Gilou, plus laughter and tears at Herville’s funeral where Beckriche gives a funny and moving eulogy. But the real emotional clout comes with the return of Tintin. The divorce, being shot in the head and leaving the squad have given Fromentin perspective, insight, and the certain knowledge that, in the end, it is not some all-consuming career, but love that counts. “Don’t mess it up,” he says intently to Gilou and Laure, like he’s some fanfic writer who has never met them. No offence, Tintin, but messing it up is kind of their thing. Laure Laure misses the surveillance operation, falling asleep in her car as she did during her under-rated homeless period. Her tardiness is, however, the only reason she is able to catch up with the fake postman and identify the Chinatown fashion connection, so yay Laure, I guess? Less stellar is her parenting performance, which hits a new low this week as she risks Romy’s life by dodging Nathalie’s calls alerting her to her daughter’s illness. It lands her in family court, with the Brémonts seeking full parental responsibility for the child. She doesn’t even put up a fight – knowing as she must by now that Romy is better off without her. Joséphine Over to Ms Karlsson, who’s been putting in some hours doing pro bono family law for heroin addict inmate Mélanie (it’s just as well for Romy that Laure didn’t have her in her corner). Spotting a fine legal distinction between kidnapping and parental child abduction that Mélanie’s lawyer missed, she offers her new client knowledge that will secure her release. All she asks in return is that the dope getting hurled over the wall into the yard now goes to Lola. It’s a fair deal. Later, Joséphine and Lola bond through the cell bars of solitary after throwing down with Sabine the crooked guard. I’d like to say friendship or romance is on the cards, but the smart money is on an apocalyptic crimewave. Meanwhile, on Joséphine’s attempted murder rap, Edelman pulls out all the stops in a crime scene reconstruction that seems to show that Vern could not possibly have identified Joséphine on the night in question. That’s just the tonic a girl needs – but when her old nemesis Judge Wagner insists on a reconstruction of his own, you can hear the facepalm from the moon. Roban François and Catherine Micallef continue to use M Vouters’ fatal haemorrhage as a springboard for their outrageous flirting. It’s a tale as old as time – a principled overworked doc – struggling to hit hospital targets – warns the suits about chronic understaffing, is roundly ignored and then forced to carry the can when the inevitable avoidable death occurs. If anyone knows about fighting the system, it’s Roban, and it’s safe to say he’s finding the case for the defence very persuasive right now. Someone get a round of Calvados in. Notes and observations • Below-the-line Flic of the Week goes to MatthewCobb, who could see that Fouad was a wrong ’un from the jump. Trust no one on this show. • Nathalie Brémont continues to be the most understanding wife in history, raising her husband’s love child without complaint, phoning Laure around the clock to arrange children’s parties or save her daughter’s life. • Edelman remains the sleazy lawyer we all love to hate, but as he calls in a favour from his Bar Association president friend for Joséphine, we get the strong impression it’s for love. As touching as that is, I don’t see it ending well. • The prefect (a senior civil servant) lets Beckriche know that any operations in the garment district will need Lenoir’s personal approval. Political expedience trumps law enforcement once again. Procureur Machard would be proud. Just how deep is Fouad in the money-laundering racket? Will Joséphine beat the rap? How long before Roban and Dr Micallef are an item? Over to you …
